metadata.title: Evaluation of the nanofluid and nano-PCM based photovoltaic thermal (PVT) system_ An experimental study

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Energy Conversion and Management
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/enconman
Evaluation of the nanofluid and nano-PCM based photovoltaic thermal (PVT) system: An experimental study
Ali H.A. Al-Waelia,⁎, K. Sopiana,⁎, Miqdam T. Chaichanb, Hussein A. Kazemc,⁎, Adnan Ibrahima, Sohif Mata, Mohd Hafidz Ruslana
a Solar Energy Research Institute, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600 Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia b Energy and Renewable Energies Technology Research Center, Baghdad, Iraq c Faculty of Engineering, Sohar University, PO Box 44, Sohar PCI 311, Oman
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: PV/T Collectors Nanofluid Nano-SiC Nano-PCM
A B S T R A C T
The increase in the PV cell temperature ultimately causes a reduction in its effectiveness. One of the new methods used to retain that efficiency is to establish a hybrid photovoltaic thermal PV/T system. In this study, PCM has been employed with a cooling nanofluid circulation system in order to the control heat capacitance of the system to maintain electrical efficiency on the one hand, and to raise the overall efficiency on the other. Nano-SiC particles were used in paraffin-PCM and nanofluid to establish higher thermal conductivities and therefore higher efficiency. The design is tested outdoors in Selangor, Malaysia.
The tests were conducted using a fluid flow rate of 0.17 kg/s. The proposed system reduced the cell temperature (30 °C) at the peak solar radiation period (12:30 AM to 1:30 PM), which was reflected positively on the PV/T system performance. The proposed PV/T-nano PCM-nanofluid system increased the open circuit voltage from 11–13 V to 20–21 V, the power from 61.1 W to 120.7 W, and the electrical efficiency from 7.1% to 13.7%. Besides, the system made use of the thermal energy gained as its thermal efficiency reached 72%. These results ensure the adequate use of the new design.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The continuous expansion in solar energy applications has called for an increase in the overall efficiency of photovoltaic systems. The nature of photovoltaics (PV) varies depending on the material it is composed of, but generally, most PV panels suffer from efficiency reduction due to an increase in cell temperature which has been proven to reduce its Open Circuit voltage (Voc), this decrease could be avoided by introducing cooling methods [1]. Chow et al. [2] have found that a 10 °C temperature rise can cause a reduction of 5% in the PV panel efficiency [2]. One way is to combine photovoltaics and solar thermal collectors in order to establish a hybrid system that benefits the two, known as Photovoltaic-Thermal (PV/T).
The use of a hybrid PV/T maintains the cell temperature and increases the output temperature of the thermal collector. Other benefits include saving up space by utilising the two systems in the same area and reducing installation costs [3]. Furthermore, it is valid to assume that more enhancements of the PV/T systems can be done by implementing different design structures and employing various materials within an acceptable amount that does not cause poor costs of energy or
extended pay-back periods [4]. The overall efficiency of PV/T units is equal to the summation of the PV electrical efficiency and the solar thermal efficiency.
The working fluid along with collector configurations are the two most important elements of classifying PV/T systems, where some systems may use water, air, a mix of the two or nanofluids. Also, the collector may have a tube and sheet configuration, heat pipe, etc. [5–8]. The cell cover of the collector is also considered to classify the PV/T collectors where research studies on the effects of glazing have shown tremendous overall effects [9]. The most commonly used a type of PV/T is an air-based one, due to its simplicity and initial costs. However, implementing liquid as a working fluid, such as water, is better for the thermal capacitance of such systems, which yields better cooling [10].
More advances lead to the use of nanofluids; nanopowder mixed with a particular liquid to produce a fluid with higher thermal conductivity to enhance the heat transfer characteristics of PV/Ts. Different nanofluids have been tested for various system configurations in order to establish a higher overall system efficiency [11]. Devendiran and Amirtham [12] conducted a review of different preparation techniques of metal and metal oxide nanofluids, along with their effect on the

physical and chemical characteristics. Bajestan et al. [13] found a 21% enhancement of the heat transfer coefficient on average when the TiO2water nanofluid was used on laminar convective heat transfer by numerically modelling the experimental testing it. Adriana [14] studied the thermophysical properties of three oxide-based nanofluids. The study concluded that the use of nanofluids enhanced the thermal conductivity by at least 12%, and raised the convective heat transfer coefficient. Hassani et al. [15] theoretically performed an exergy life cycle analysis of nanofluid-based PV/T with three variable arrangements. The life cycle exergy results indicate a higher performance in the nanofluid-based PV/T system compared to the traditional ones. Sardarabadi and Fard [16] evaluated the cooling effect of three metal oxide nanofluids (Al2O3, TiO2, ZnO) experimentally and numerically. The ZnO/water nanofluid was found to cause the highest thermal efficiency in comparison with the other two nanofluids and deionized water- based PV/T. Hjerrild et al. [17] used Ag-SiO2 nanofluid and CNT in water. These materials were used because of thier sun light absorbing properties. Ag-SiO2 was found to increase the combined efficiency to 30% compared to the base fluid filter. The electrical efficiency achieved was around 6.6%.
Sardarabadi et al. [18] investigated the SiO2-nanofluid effects experimentally as a coolant on the efficiency of the PV/T systems (both electrical and thermal). The results showed an overall system efficiency increase of 3.6% when 1.0 wt% was used compared to water, while 3.0% weight fraction produced a total efficiency increase of up to 7.9%. Radwan et al. [19] examined the volume fraction and mass flow rate of Al2O3 and SiC–water nanofluids on the performance of the PV/T system. Authors concluded that using the SiC–water nanofluid leads to a higher reduction in the PV panel temperature, compared to Al2O3–water. An et al. [20] conducted outdoor experiments in Shanghai, China for a concentrated PV/T with a spectral splitting filter when using a Cu9S5 (oleylamine solution) nanofluid as the base fluid for cooling the entity. The thermal energy obtained exceeded 100 °C and the overall efficiency of the unit has raised by around 17%.
Khanjari et al. [21] considered two types of nanofluids; Ag-water and Al2O3-water nanofluids, as coolants of the PV/T system. A CFD simulation was made for the entity. The study results indicated that the Ag-water showed the highest percentage increase in the heat transfer coefficient with 43%, while alumina-water leads to a 12% increase. Hussien et al. [22] conducted an experimental investigation of the Al2O3-water nanofluid with forced convection as a coolant of the PV/T systems. Various nanofluid concentrations were implemented, from 0.1 to 0.5 with step 0.1%, to test the effect of the mass fraction. The results obtained showed that the PV module temperature was around 79.1 °C when water was used alone as the base fluid. Manikandan and Rajan [23] tested the thermophysical properties of sand-propylene glycolwater, surfactant free, for solar energy collection through experiments. Thermo-physical properties, of 2% volume, showed a reduction in viscosity and enhancement in thermal conductivity of around 47% and 16.3%, respectively.
Ghadiri et al. [24] experimentally tested the effects of the Fe3O4water nanofluid on a PV/T system, when varying concentration, regarding the overall efficiency and exergy. Water and ferrofluid (Fe3O4water) with concentrations of 1% and 3% were used. Furthermore, the ferrofluids were subjected to constant and variable magnetic fields. The 3% concentration of the ferrofluid caused improvements in the overall efficiency of the system for about 45%. Crisostomo et al. [25] developed an optical and heat transfer model of a concentrating PV/T system with Ag-SiO2/water nanofluid with a filter and validated the model through outdoor experiments of a prototype of the system. The results obtained showed an increase of 12% in the weighted energy output compared to the conventional PV system. Rejeb et al. [26] evaluated the performance of nanofluid based PV/T by considering water, ethylene glycol, Cu/ethylene glycol, Cu/water, Al2O3/water & Al2O3/ethylene glycol as the base fluids, and considering three cities: Lyon, Mashhad, and Monastir of France, Iran, and Tunisia, respectively. Using
Cu/water in the Monastir city increased efficiencies and output, where the annual electrical energy and thermal energy outputs were around 746 kWh/m2 and 1842 kWh/m2, respectively.
Michael et al. [27] presented a novel design of PV/T with the copper sheet laminated directly to the PV cell and CuO nanofluid as working fluid, the addition of surfactant was also investigated along with the glazing-effect. The maximum electrical and thermal efficiencies achieved for the PV/T with glazing are 6.18% and 30.43%, while the maximum electrical and thermal efficiencies for the collector without glazing are 7.62% and 28.22%. There are more papers published in the last two years and some of these papers are in the field of PV/T nanofluids based systems, which should be reviewed by the interested researchers such as Refs. [28–30].
Another method of maintaining cell temperature is the use of phase change material (PCM) to increase thermal capacitance because of its ability to store excess solar power for later use. A commonly used material with PCM properties is paraffin wax. Paraffin wax is used for heat storage applications because it contains a high heat and storage capacity on a wide range of temperatures and is inexpensive, non-toxic, and environmentally friendly. In particularly, reference is made to organic paraffins, which are safe and efficient materials that can withstand constant cycles of melting and freezing for such applications [31]. Some work is done in combining PV/T and PCM or nanofluids. However, this area needs further investigation to present the best possible solution to increasing photovoltaic thermal collectors and reducing their costs of energy along with boosting commercial sales of solar energy based systems.
Smith et al. [32] examined the impact of the PCM with different melting temperatures, ranging from 0 °C to 50 °C to identify the best PCM melting temperature for various locations, by implementing a onedimensional energy balance model to simulate the system. The simulation results show a 6% increase in the annual PV power output in Mexico and eastern Africa, while it showed an increase of 5% for the Arabia region, Southern Asia, Central and South America, and much of Africa. Al-Imam et al. [33] conducted an outdoors experiment of a compound parabolic concentrator (CPC) photovoltaic thermal PV/T system with PCM to investigate the solar energy conversion into thermal energy, thermal efficiency and total, and the element of heat storage. The results obtained showed that the overall PV/T efficiencies achieved for sunny and semi-cloudy days were ranging around 55–63% and 46%–55%, respectively. Elarga et al. [34] investigated the dynamic-thermal behaviour and performance of a PCM-PV system in double skin facades (DSF) in different climates (Venice, Helsinki and Abu Dhabi) numerically. The authors claimed that the system causes a monthly reduction in cooling energy demands by 20–30% while the increase in PVs' electric power with a peak value is around 5–8%.
Gaur et al. [35] are developing a mathematical model for a thermal and electrical investigation for exergy and efficiency of a water-based PV/T system with and without PCM. OM37 was used as a PCM for typical winter and summer days in Lyon, France. Authors claimed that the system shows better results in both summer and winter. Browne et al. [36] proposed a novel design of a water-based PV/T system with PCM through thermosyphon flow and a heat exchanger, for Dublin, Ireland and tested it for outdoor conditions. The study results clarified that using PCM was an efficient method of storing heat. Hasan et al. [37] measured the impact of PCM on the building integrated PV (BIPV) system, by enhancing the PV module efficiency and capitalising on the lost temperature. The study deals with five types of PCMs with melting temperatures varied from 25 ± 4 °C and heat of fusion ranging from 140 to 213 kJ/kg. The highest reduction in PV temperature was around 18 °C.
Biwole et al. [38] presented a CFD model of heat and mass transfer for the PV panel with a row PCM. The simulation includes the thermophysical change of properties, and an experimental set-up was used to validate the work. The simulation shows that a PCM can maintain a 40 °C panel temperature for approximately two hours under a constant
solar radiation of 1 kW/m2. Kazanci et al. [39] investigated the use of PCM in a photovoltaic/thermal (PV/T) for a plus-energy house to sustain its heating and cooling. The results obtained showed that the PV/T efficiency was around 42.8%, while the conventional PV was at 13.59%. Qiu et al. [40] theoretically investigated a new PV/T design that employed the MPCM (Microencapsulated Phase Change Material) slurry, regarding energy performance. The results revealed that the maximum achieved electrical efficiency was 8.7% while the maximum achieved thermal efficiency was 59%.
Hassan et al. [41] conducted an electrical and thermal energy efficiency analysis for a solid-liquid PCM integrated into PV panels’ PV temperature regulation and cooling, in two different climates. The results indicated that the average achieved efficiencies for Ireland and Pakistan are 14.6% and 20.3%, respectively. Fiorentini et al. [42] studied a new air-based photovoltaic–thermal (PV/T) collector with the addition of a PCM storage unit integrated with a reverse cycle heat pump for an HVAC application. The maximum generated electrical efficiency was 9% while the maximum thermal efficiency was 45%. Stropnik and Stritih [43] numerically investigated the effect of adding PCM to the PV/T system on the electrical efficiency using a TRNSYS software application and panel temperature and compared the results with experimental data to know the effects. The simulation results indicated that the power production of the PV/T with PCM was 7.3% higher than its counterpart, for a one-year period. The maximum achieved electrical efficiency was 13%.
Karunamurthy et al. [44] incorporated CuO nanoparticles in paraffin PCM to improve its thermal conductivity, which allows it to overcome the relatively low rate of heat transfer in the thermal energy storage applications. In other works, Sardarabadi et al. [45] designed, built and performed an experimental study on a ZnO-nanofluid based PV/T collector with paraffin-PCM. The nanofluid runs in the pipes which are emerged in the PCM storage tank. The use of both techniques has raised the electrical output of PV/T 13% over the conventional PV model.
This study will merge the two techniques by dispersing SiC nanoparticles in paraffin wax as a PCM and placing it in a container that will carry the PV panel, which to the best of author’s knowledge, is a novel method and design of PV/T systems. The pipes within the container will hold the working fluid which will be nanofluid SiC-water. This will further increase the thermal performance of the PV/T and maintain its electrical efficiency. This paper presents a novel design of PCM-nano and nanofluid based PV/T system that is designed, fabricated and tested outdoors.

sections.heading: 2.1. Study area
sections.text: Bangi, Selangor Malaysia is the site in which the system was setup. The location coordinates are 2.9021 N, 101.7830 E (latitude close to that of Kuala Lumpur, and city close in distance as well). The weather patterns are generally estimated to be around 31 °C in temperature with a wind speed of 10 km/h and approximate humidity of 66% [7,11]. The average approximated monthly hours of sunshine are between 150 and 210 h, while the average monthly rainy days over the year are between 14 days in July (lowest) and 20 days in October, November and April (peak). The biomes of Bangi include Forrest, mountains and hills.

sections.heading: 2.2. New design description
sections.text:
The new idea in this study is that the PV/T system includes a tank containing a phase change material (PCM) with a high thermal storage capacity that stores the heat transferred from the PV panel. The high thermal storage of the PCM makes it receive all the heat transfers from the PV panel. Therefore, a fluid cycle is placed in the tank to remove the stored heat to an external heat exchanger, increasing the temperature
difference between the PV panel and PCM, and hence enhancing the heat transfer process and reducing the PV panel temperature, which improves its performance. To improve the charging and discharging processes, the PCM used in the study (paraffin wax) was mixed with nano-SiC particles. The importance of the charging and discharging processes allows them to provide increasingly efficient cooling to the proposed system.
The PCM starts to harden when the temperature is below its melting temperature. This is due to sub cooling (also called super cooling). The PCM will not release the entire latent heat stored at its melting temperature due to the sub cooling effect. The sub-cooling allows the PCM to crystallise well under the phase change temperature at which the latent heat is released. During the fusion process (charging process), the appearance of any sub-cooling effect does not cause any difference in the process, but during the cooling process (discharging process), is an important factor. When the temperature of a PCM reaches values below its melting temperature, it will then begin to crystallise [46]. Crystallization is an important factor in releasing latent heat during the process of solidification. As the crystallisation process begins, the nuclei begin to form, which is the basic process: the nuclei are divided into two types; homogenous and heterogeneous [47]. In homogenous nuclei, The PCM itself makes modulation due to sufficient heat temperature. In heterogeneous nuclei, the process does not start by the PCM itself, but because of the special additives that are intentionally added to the PCM, as in the recent study. The addition of nanoparticles and their dispersion in wax as a cores agent will reduce the time of solidification and melting. These nanoparticles can form heterogeneous nuclei in the PCM compound [48]. This is a very important topic but it is not part of the research scope, so the interested reader can return to Refs. [49–51].
One of the drawbacks of the PCM is the decrease in its performance throughout time. The addition of nanoparticles greatly increases the total recoverable energy from the PCM and can be attributed to the high increase in the heat transfer rate due to these particles. Ref. [52] noted that the addition of nanoparticles works to promote the recovered exergy from paraffin wax by reducing the time of solidification. Ref. [53] declared experimentally that the fusion and re-crystallisation of the paraffin wax did not change after 30 cycles of heating/cooling, and the thermophysical properties remained constant over five cycles of heat.
The experimental setup was established in the green innovation and technology parks' outdoors laboratory, which is a part of the UKM (National University of Malaysia). The schematic diagram and view of the main experimental rig are shown in Figs. 1 and 2, respectively. The setup is composed of a supporting pole, which is used to carry the PV panels. The PV panels were set to face the south at an angle of 14° depending on the results of Refs. [54,55]. The system also contains a cabinet which contains a heat exchanger, water pumps, nanofluid container, laptop, and a data acquisition system. Behind the enclosure, a water tank was installed to hold the produced thermal output. The PCM container was isolated from its back and sides with glass wool with a 2 cm thickness to prevent heat leakage to the ambient. This insulation will make all the heat drawn from the PV panel aggregate in the reservoir and then pull out via water and nanofluid. It is worth to mention that Figs. 1 and 2 illustrate the proposed system, while the remaining configurations are similar and setup in the park as well, with their separate heat exchangers, tanks and systems.
The new PV/T design is compared to different setups in the work; four combinations were designed to test the effectiveness of this design. These systems are: the conventional PV system, PV/T with container filled with water and water as working fluid, PV/T with container filled with PCM and water as working fluid, PV/T with container filled with nanoparticles dispersed in PCM with nanofluid as working fluid. The reason behind establishing these systems is to add elements of validation to the claim and test the system’s performance. The data of all PV/ T systems and PV system were collected simultaneously.

sections.heading: 2.3. Design of the PCM/Nanofluid based PV/T
sections.text:
The PV/T design criteria were seeking to use less material for the selected photovoltaic size to avoid heat losses and guarantee fewer costs. Galvanized steel was used in order to build the PCM container attached to the back of the panel and copper pipes were used to carry the base fluid, given that copper is an excellent thermal conductor and is commonly used for such applications. Figs. 3 and 4 show a crosssection schematic diagram of the system and top view diagram of the collector, respectively. Table 1 shows the specification of the NanoPCM/PV/T collector.
As Figs. 3 and 4 indicate, a silicon oil layer is placed between the PV panel and the PCM tank. This is to guarantee that no air gaps are present, as well as to increase the thermal capacitance of the collector. Two pipes in the top are made, one to insert the PCM and the air, while the other is to release air bubbles from the collector. As for the bottom tube, it is designed to ensure the removal of the containers' contents. Fig. 5 shows a photo of the collector. It is important to note that the conventional PV panels used have the same sizes to those utilised for the novel design to ensure a fair comparison between the two. Table 2 shows the properties of the PV panels used.
(a) Data Acquisition System, (b) Structure mounted on pole, (c) Pyranometer, (d) Flowmeter, (e) Heat exchanger and
(f) Proposed collector.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of the nanofluid and nano-PCM
sections.text:
The preparation of nanomaterial was made over two steps: the first being implemented to be dispersed in paraffin (PCM) and the second being implemented to produce a nanofluid. Different nanoparticle mass fraction values (wt.%) were taken into consideration to be dispersed in the paraffin wax by creating several samples with the same amount of paraffin and different amounts of SiC nanopowder. The mass fractions are 0%, 0.1%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, 3% and 4%. All added SiC nanoparticles can be seen in Fig. 6a. The mixing process was completed using an Ultrasonic Shaker (TELSONIC ULTRASONICS CT-I2) bath with a volume of 12 litres, which performed the heating (800 W), and a perfect shaking of the samples for 60 min (30 kHz), which ensured no sedimentation and optimum dispersion occurred and that a homogeneous and stable suspension was formed as well. These samples were taken to two testing stages; the first stage is the visual test; whether the addition of SiC-nanoparticles and ultra-sonication changed the colour of the
paraffin or not. Perhaps the first evidence of the complete amalgamation of nanoparticles in wax is the color change and homogeneity in all prepared wax-nano-SiC samples. The second stage is the thermo-physical properties test, in which the properties of the sample such as fluidity, viscosity, and thermal conductivity are measured to verify the enhancement the paraffin has received. Table 3 shows the specifications of the used nano-SiC, while Table 4 represents the tested paraffin wax specifications. Once a certain mass fraction is chosen from the tests, it is applied for a relatively large-scale production for the PCM container, as can be seen in Fig. 6b.
As for the mixing process to produce a SiC-water nanofluid, similar steps are followed that involve the consideration of several weight percentages, use of ultrasonic shaking, and thermophysical properties testing. After the selection of a specified adding percentage of nano-SiC for the paraffin wax and the nanofluid, the produced material is further studied through the use of a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), which can provide an elucidation of the topographic surface of the SiC nanoparticles. Fig. 7 shows the FESEM image of the silicon carbide nanoparticles with and without paraffin and their presence which is proved to be ranging from 40 to 60 nm. Also, an Electron Dispersion X-ray (EDX) image and an Electron Dispersion Spectroscopy (EDS) were taken for the SiC-paraffin sample. EDX and EDS are simple but useful techniques for determining the morphological composition of less than one cubic micron per substance. This equipment is attached to the Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) to facilitate the collection of elemental information from the sample under examination. This technique is non-destructive and has 0.1% sensitivity to elements that are heavier than carbon. Also, an X-ray diffraction (XRD) image was taken of the SiC and SiC-paraffin samples. Having a range of images to validate the state and properties of the mix allows a further understanding the impact of employing SiC nanoparticles in paraffin. The analysis and discussion of the FESEM, EDX, and XRD images are presented in the results and discussion. Figs. 8–10 show the EDX, EDS, and XRD of the SiC-paraffin sample, respectively.
The Solar Energy Research Institute (SERI) laboratory was used to conduct the thermophysical properties tests. The main elements to be tested are the density, viscosity, heat capacity and thermal conductivity of the nanofluid and nano-PCM material. The DII-300L Leading Factory Liquid Density Tester was used to measure the samples' density, while the Brookfield programmable viscometer (model: LVDV-III ultra-programmable) was used for its viscosity, which was done for the variable volume concentrations at variable temperatures. As for the thermal conductivity of the samples, a KD2 Pro analyzer.lr thermal property

The SiC-water nanofluid preparation for the experiments was done in the same manner as used in Ref. [11]. The thermophysical properties test results were similar, so that the interested reader could return to this reference for more details. The stability of the nanofluid has been ascertained for more than six months as it is included in Ref. [11], which is an acceptable time for the circulation and use of this nanofluid.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characteristics of the selected equipment
sections.text:
In-between the panel, an apogee meter pyranometer was placed to measure the solar radiation that strikes the area. K-type thermocouple
temperature sensors were attached to the inlet pipe, outlet pipe, face of the PV panels and backs of the container, as well as multimeters were used for the current and voltage measurements. A flow meter type polysulphone-flow meter (manufacture in China) was used to measure the water and nanofluid flow. Table 5 shows the specifications of the equipment used along with the measurement parameter.

sections.heading: 2.7. Uncertainty analysis
sections.text:
Ensuring that the results are correct is necessary in order to prevent
Fig. 9. EDS of SiC-Paraffin nanoparticles.
measurement errors from crawling on all trials despite the care exercised. Some of these errors are random; some are due to the human side errors caused by the examiner. Sometimes bad data can be identified by obvious errors and disposed of immediately. However, bad data points will be identified, as it is unacceptable to dispose of some data because they are not in line with our expectations unless the error is obviously shown. These bad points are usually located outside the expected random deviation, and such data can be eliminated using a consistent statistical data analysis. Here, the human freaks and prejudices must not interfere on the basis of what “must be” [56].

sections.heading: 2.8. Test procedure
sections.text:
In this study, nano-SiC was added to water to form the nanofluid with a mass fraction of 3% depending on the results of Refs. [11,58], such that the interested reader can return to these references for more details. The locally produced paraffin wax in Malaysia, whose thermal properties are shown in Table 4, was used. The most significant defect in the paraffin wax as a phase change material is its low thermal conductivity. For comparison purposes, paraffin wax was used as a neat and was mixed with nano-SiC. Nano-SiC was chosen because it is moderately priced and locally available but also due to its high thermal conductivity. After filling the tanks with wax and nano-SiC-wax, the liquid wax is left to solidify using cooling water and nanofluid circulation in the inner tubes. After ensuring that the paraffin wax has
completely hardened, the reservoirs are ready for testing. The following systems have been designed, installed and measurements have been taken:
• Conventional PV (PV). • PV/T-cooling tank filled with water and water flows through cooling pipes (PVT. w). • PV/T-cooling tank filled with PCM and water flows through cooling pipes (PVT. pcm. w). • PV/T-cooling tank filled with PCM/nano-SiC and nanofluid (waterSiC) flows through cooling pipes (PVT. n-pcm. nf).
The first experiments were conducted to elucidate the thermophysical properties of both the nanofluid and the nano- wax. After ascertaining the efficiency and stability of the materials used, the field trials began. Experiments were conducted on sunny and clear days starting from 3rd of June 2017. Measurements started at 8 AM and ended at sunset. The fluid pumps remained active after sunset to cool the paraffin wax and continued to work until it was confirmed that the wax temperature reached the temperature of the entering fluid and was completely solidified to be ready for the following experiments.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text: The PV/PVT systems were installed and data was recorded. Because of the rainy and cloudy weather conditions, the clear sky days were selected.

sections.heading: 3.1. Thermophysical properties of nanofluid, PCM, nano-PCM
sections.text:
Since paraffin wax is not a flowing substance in the system, such as the nanofluid, then the changing in density and viscosity are not at the same level of importance of its thermal conductivity and thermal capacity. However, the density was measured at 25 °C and the changes were found (0.01, 0.02, 0.024, 0.028, 0.029, 0.31%) for the added SiC mass fractions of (0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4%) respectively. The effect of the addition of nano-SiC on the wax's viscosity became clearer as the viscosity increased by (0.1, 0.22, 0.27, 0.34, 0.42 and 0.55%) to the addition of (0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, 3 and 4%) of the nano-SiC, respectively. Basically, viscosity does not enter as an effective variable in the studied system due to the wax's stillness and lack of movement. The relative thermal conductivity enhancement was calculated depending on Ref. [56], which introduced the relative thermal conductivity enhancement by the equation:
= −Relative thermal conductivity enhancement rate (k k )/k0 0 (7)
This equation describes the possibility of an additive added to enhancing the thermal conductivity quantitatively. In the same manner, the relative thermal capacity rate was calculated using the equation:

Fig. 11 declares the changes in the relative thermal conductivity and capacity vs. the added nano-SiC proportion to the PCM. The test was conducted at 25 °C to eliminate the impact of temperature variation on the measurement. The thermal conductivity improved with the addition of nano-SiC to the PCM with a nanoparticle mass concentration of 0.1% of wax weight that was 22 kg. By adding other amounts of nano-SiC, the improvement in the thermal conductivity of wax was minor and was not commensurate with the added financial cost of the system. The same applies to the heat capacity of the paraffin wax, as its increase was very small and not adequate. The relative thermal capacity enhancement showed slight increases in value. The increment variation rate after the 0.1% nano-SiC addition was insignificant. For this reason, 0.1% of the nano-SiC mass fraction was selected to be added to the paraffin wax. This ratio enhanced the thermal conductivity of the wax, and it is small and does not increase the cost of the system adversely.

sections.heading: 3.2. Thermal results analysis
sections.text:
Before the experiments, the optimal nanofluid water flow rates should be determined for the system to reduce the number of tests. For this purpose, PCM and water were used to determine the best flow rate that causes the greatest decrease in the temperature of the PV panel used. Fig. 12 shows that the PV panel temperature decreased by increasing the flow rate from 0.083 kg/s to 0.17 kg. Increasing the flow
rate of any fluid causes an increase in heat exchange and a greater heat transfer from a hot medium to a colder one. Of course, the water flow rate could be increased to 0.583 kg/s, but a vibration began to appear in the PV/T system that forced to eliminate the tests in this range of flow rates (0.083–0.17 kg/s). Therefore, the remaining experiments will be conducted using a flow rate of 0.175 kg/s.
Fig. 13 shows the daytime temperature distribution of the systems used in the tests. The PV panel temperature for all systems starts at temperatures higher than the ambient temperature because they heat up since sunrise and before taking the measurements. The individual PV panel temperature was higher than the rest of the systems, as it depended on the heat transfer to ambient air. The rest of the systems' temperatures were from the highest to the lowest as follows: PVT cell. w, PVT cell. PCM. w, and PVT cell n-PCM nf. Although water has a relatively higher specific heat than the nanofluid, it lacks the thermal conductivity of the latter. The use of nanofluid significantly reduced the temperature of the panel. Also, the use of PCM in the system caused a larger draw of the heat collected in the PV panel, due to the wax's high thermal storage capacity. From here, it is easy to analyse why the temperature of the solar panel is greater than the surrounding air several degrees before sunset, because of the heat stored in the paraffin wax. Adding nano-SiC to wax enhanced its thermal conductivity and increased the heat exchange with the nanofluid. According to the insignificant effect of nanoparticles on the thermal properties of the PCM (see Fig. 11), it seems that the main effect corresponds to the nanofluid.

It acquired heat from the PV panel more rapidly than other studied systems and transferred it to the nanofluid more quickly. The PVT cell n-PCM, nf. system has reduced the temperature of the solar panel impressively as the PV panel temperature in this system did not exceed 39 °C while the PV panel alone temperature reached 68.3 °C.
Fig. 14 compares the acquired thermal energy in the PV/T systems studied during the operating time. The addition of nanomaterial, whether water or wax, increases the amount of heat transferred to the nanofluid. When the medium from which the heat is transported has a higher thermal conductivity, the amount of thermal energy transferred increases as in the PVT cell n-PCM, nf. Larger heat dissipation from a PV/T system means that the PV panel work is maintained in conditions relatively close to the standard conditions, as well as the utilisation of the heat drawn will be greater. Besides, although there is a considerable temperature fluctuation due to the instantaneous change of solar radiation, the use of PCM dampens this oscillation during the heat elimination process. The use of water as a cooling fluid with wax caused the temperature of the phase change material to remain high from 4 PM to 6 PM. The use of nanofluid with wax mixed with nano-SiC caused a significant decrease in the temperature of the paraffin wax for the same period. The reason for this is the low thermal conductivity of water and wax in the first case offset by the high thermal conductivity of the
nanofluid and wax mixed with nanoparticles. The nano-paraffin wax in this period begins to lose the heat to the nanofluid (discharge process) without acquiring new heat, which explains the rapid decline in the temperature of the last case.
The heat drawn from the PV/T utilises systems in many applications that cannot be obtained from the PV system. In the case of using the PV panel, there is no thermal efficiency as in the PV/T systems. Fig. 15 shows the thermal efficiency distribution of the studied PV/T systems over time. The three systems had close values at the beginning of the tests because the PV panels were not heated enough to transfer thermal energy to the cooling fluids. The use of nanomaterials with PCM and nanofluid has given a high thermal efficiency added to the electrical efficiency that will be certainly improved by the reduction of the PV panel temperature. The high thermal efficiency in the case of wax mixed with nano-SiC and nanofluid as a cooling fluid indicates that the proposed system pulls most of the heat of the solar panel. It also allows the conversion of heat drawn into thermal energy that can be used in many applications. The presence of nanofluid in the system causes a significant improvement in heat transfer and this is what caused the close values of PVT cell.pcm.n.nf with PVT cell.pcm.w values at the end of the tests.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrical results analysis
sections.text:
Figs. 16 and 17 show the recorded electrical parameters with respect to solar radiation, temperatures, voltages, and currents, respectively. The PV/PVT voltage waveform is more affected by solar radiation rather than current. However, the current waveform is more consistent with solar radiation than the voltage waveform. Moreover, the fluctuation and spikes in the voltage and current waveforms are due to the change in solar radiation. A small change in solar radiation is reflected on the voltage and current waveforms because of their low values. The voltages are ranged 11–13 V, 13–14 V, 18–20 V and 20–21 V for the PV, PVT.w, PVT.pcm.w and PVT.pcm.n.nf systems, respectively. Also, the average voltages were found at 12.2 V, 13.3 V, 19.7 V and 20.6 V, respectively. However, the voltage curve was flat compared to the current curve shown in Figs. 17 and 18. The current curve is more closely related to the solar radiation curve, as long as the two curves are analogical together in shape. However, the maximum measured current was 6.7 A, 6.8 A, 6.9 A and 7.1 A for the PV, PVT.w, PVT.pcm.w and PVT.pcm.n.nf systems, respectively.
electrical output power variation during the experimental period for the tested systems. It is clearly seen that the PVT.pcm.n.nf has the highest production. The tested systems’ highest generated powers were 61.1 W, 85.7 W, 116.1 W and 120.7 W, respectively. Fig. 19 shows a comparison of the electrical efficiency for different systems. The results clearly indicate that the PVT.pcm.n.nf has a maximum efficiency with 13.7%. However, PVT.pcm.w is in the second position with 11.3%, then PVT.w with 8.6% and finally PV with 7.1%. These results proved that the use of nanoparticles with PCM and water in one system enhances the electrical efficiency significantly because of the reduction in the PV temperature.
Even with the current-status of PV, many challenges continue to face this technology, which can be summarised as degradation due to environmental elements. A reduction of 5% in efficiency is resultant in an increase of the cell temperature by 10 °C [2,59]. The sporadic productivity and uncertainty of the PV is a definite issue. The changing of solar radiation and temperature causes fluctuations in the output, which might render the technology unreliable [60,61]. Thus, the PVs' instantaneous output power can be calculated by [31],

Eq. (9) shows that solar radiation and temperature are the main variables, which specify the PV power production.
Since the PV current and voltage are significantly affected by the PV cell temperature, Fig. 17 shows the correlation between voltage and the PV cell temperature. The figure reveals the inverse proportionality between voltage and temperature. The cooling of the PV cell using the proposed PVT.pcm.n.nf produced more voltage with minimum cell temperature compared to the other three systems. However, the voltage increase enhanced the generated power as Fig. 18 illustrates. Ref. [62] summarised various correlations between the temperature and PV efficiency proposed in the literature. However, the authors claimed that attention in applying a particular expression for the operating temperature of a PV module is important because the available equations have been developed with a specific mounting geometry or building
integration level in mind. Fig. 19 shows the relation between solar irradiance, PV cell temperature, and electrical efficiency. From Fig. 19, it is found that the proposed PVT.pcm.n.nf system gave the highest electrical efficiency 13.7% due to the improvement of voltage and power as discussed in Figs. 17 and 18. Table 6 summarised some important results in Figs. 12–19. The table illustrates that the PV temperature declined, while the output cooling fluid output temperature, thermal energy, and electrical power, maximum thermal and electrical efficiencies increased for the PVT systems. However, the increase in the maximum thermal efficiency is significant with respect to the electrical efficiency.
Figs. 20 and 21 show a comparison of the PV and PVT efficiencies in the literature, respectively [9,63–81]. The compared efficiencies range between 4.7–13.7% and 33.2–85.7% for electrical and total efficiencies, respectively. It is not acceptable to determine the difference in efficiencies due to solar cell cooling. There are different affected parameters related to the used technologies, location, weather parameters, system configuration, the thermal system type, and cooling methods. The overall comparison is particularly difficult because of the different circumstances of each study. sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, a new PVT system was proposed. The system consists of a tank filled with paraffin wax mixed with nano-SiC to enhance its thermal conductivity. The nanofluid component of a mixture of nanoSiC and water passes through the wax in copper tubes. The performance of the system is compared with other systems namely the PV plate, wax tank cooled with water, water tank cooled with water.
The study showed that the proposed new system reduced the temperature of the photovoltaic cell more than other systems, especially during peak time. The temperature reduction during peak time (from 12:00 PM to 2:30 PM) was about 17 °C. Thus, it gave higher thermal energy (with about 37.84% more than the water tank cooled by water) that can be used in many applications more efficiently. The maximum thermal energy gained by the PVT.pcm.n.nf was 72% superior to the PVT. pcm.w system, whereby its thermal energy was 50.5%. This illustrates the importance of using nanofluids to cool the system.
The open circuit voltage of the new system reached 20–21 V, which is a very high value compared to the PV panel open circuit voltage which did not exceed 11–13 V. The new system current was relatively higher than the other tested systems (7.1 A compared to 6.7 for the PV panel). The electrical power of the proposed system reached 120.7 W while for the PV panel it was 61.1 W. By comparing the efficiencies resulting from the proposed system with those listed in some newly published research studies, it is shown that the total efficiency obtained from this system exceeds all the competencies involved in the comparison. As a final result, the operation of a PV/T system using nanoSiC-PCM and nanofluids improves the thermal and electrical energy and increases the overall energy of the system more than any PV/T system studied to date.

metadata.abstractText: The increase in the PV cell temperature ultimately causes a reduction in its effectiveness. One of the new methods used to retain that efficiency is to establish a hybrid photovoltaic thermal PV/T system. In this study, PCM has been employed with a cooling nanofluid circulation system in order to the control heat capacitance of the system to maintain electrical efficiency on the one hand, and to raise the overall efficiency on the other. Nano-SiC particles were used in paraffin-PCM and nanofluid to establish higher thermal conductivities and therefore higher efficiency. The design is tested outdoors in Selangor, Malaysia. The tests were conducted using a fluid flow rate of 0.17 kg/s. The proposed system reduced the cell temperature (30 °C) at the peak solar radiation period (12:30 AM to 1:30 PM), which was reflected positively on the PV/T system performance. The proposed PV/T-nano PCM-nanofluid system increased the open circuit voltage from 11–13 V to 20–21 V, the power from 61.1 W to 120.7 W, and the electrical efficiency from 7.1% to 13.7%. Besides, the system made use of the thermal energy gained as its thermal efficiency reached 72%. These results ensure the adequate use of the new design.
